item.title: Setting up new Ubuntu Workstation
item.dc:creator: Software Development Training LLC
item.description:
Table of Contents

  • Who is this post for?
  • Update and Upgrade After Initial Boot-up
  • Remove Amazon Icon from Launcher
  • Install Dropbox
  • Install Insync (Optional)
  • Install Zimwiki
  • Change Ubuntu Application Menu Location
  • Configure, Run, and Check Thunderbird
  • Install and Configure KeePass2
  • Install Chrome Browser
  • Set Up Symbolic Links in ${HOME}
  • Set Up Terminal Preferences and Profiles
  • Change Desktop Background
  • Install Emacs
  • Install Geany
  • Install Filezilla
  • Verify Anaconda Python 3 Environment
  • Install Gnome2 Tools
  • Install gitg
  • Install Unity Tweak Tool
  • Update Mouse Sensitivity

  • Install DragonDisk
  • Installing R and R Studio

  • Install/Enable SSH Server
  • Install PBS/Torque Job Scheduler on the Workstation

Who is this post for?

This post is really not likely to be useful to anybody but me. There are so many assumptions about things like: * how and where bash startup files are stored in Dropbox * how Thunderbird is already configured and the configuration files are shared across systems via Dropbox * how Zim Wiki files are shared via Dropbox * how ssh and ssh keys are configured * what tools (Emacs, Geany, etc.) you want to use * how you want things to appear in the launcher * your knowledge about using sudo * etc.

It would take a week or more to check and list all these assumptions.

This post is really just a place for me to document the steps that I have to take in order to get a new Ubuntu 16.04 LTS workstation configured for use.

Update and Upgrade After Initial Boot-up

  1. Start a terminal window (Ctrl - Alt - T)

  2. Enter the following commands

    $ sudo apt-get update
$ sudo apt-get upgrade
$ sudo apt-get install -f

Remove Amazon Icon from Launcher

  1. Right click on Amazon Icon
  2. Select Unlock from Launcer in context menu

Install Dropbox

  1. Visit Install Dropbox

  2. Download Ubuntu (.deb) 64-bit

  3. Open the .deb with Ubuntu Software Center

  4. Once Dropbox is installed, run Dropbox and configure it

    Select the Dropbox icon in the upper right and choose Preferences...

    Set the following preferences

General

  • Check the Start Dropbox on system startup box

Account

  • Link the computer to your Dropbox account

Bandwidth

  • No changes from defaults

Proxies

  • No changes from defaults

Notifications

  • Uncheck Notify me about * New files synced * Edits to files

Sync

  • Move Dropbox folder to ${HOME}/Documents

    This should end up placing the files in ${HOME}/Documents/Dropbox

  • Choose Selective Sync... and only sync

    • Apps
    • KeePass2
    • MATLAB
    • Notebooks
    • ubuntu
    • WUSTL

It may take a couple days before Dropbox folders and files are fully synced.

Install Insync (Optional)

  1. Download the 64-bit deb
  2. Open the deb (with the Ubuntu Software Center)
  3. Start insync and configure to Google accounts

Install Zimwiki

  1. In a terminal window, issue the following commands:

  2. Enter the following commands

    $ sudo apt-get update && sudo apt-get upgrade
$ sudo add-apt-repository ppa:jaap.karssenberg/zim
$ sudo apt-get install zim

  3. Open Zim and Open the Following 3 Notebooks

    • WUSTL at ${HOME}/Documents/Dropbox/Notebooks/WUSTL
    • Personal at ${HOME}/Documents/Dropbox/Notebooks/Personal
    • Training at ${HOME}/Documents/Dropbox/Notebooks/Training

  4. Set default notebook to WUSTL

  5. Lock the Zim Desktop Icon to the Launcher and move it up to the top, just below the Dash

Change Ubuntu Application Menu Location

  1. From the Dash (Ubuntu icon in upper left) enter "settings" and launch the System Settings app. (or use the System Settings icon in the launcher (looks like a gear with a wrench in front of it)
  2. Navigate to Appearance --> Behavior
  3. Under Show the menus for a window choose In the window's title bar

Configure, Run, and Check Thunderbird

  1. Thunderbird should already be installed as it is a default application for Ubuntu

  2. Before running Thunderbird for the first time

    $ cd
$ ln -s ${HOME}/Documents/Dropbox/ubuntu/.thunderbird

  3. Run Thunderbird and check accounts, folders, sending mail, etc.

  4. Lock the Thunderbird Mail icon to the Launcher and move it up to just below the Zim Desktop Wiki icon

Install and Configure KeePass2

  1. Issue the following commands to install KeePass2

    $ sudo add-apt-repository ppa:jtaylor/keepass
$ sudo apt-get update
$ sudo apt-get install keepass2

  2. Run KeePass2 from the Dash

  3. Open KeePass2 database file - in synced Dropbox

  4. Lock the KeePass2 icon to the Launcher

  5. In running KeePass2, choose Tools --> Options... and select Lock workspace after KeePass inactivity (seconds): 300

Install Chrome Browser

  1. Visit https:://www.google.com/chrome
  2. Select the Download Chrome button
  3. Select 64 bit .deb (For Debian/Ubuntu)
  4. Select Accept and Install

Set Up Symbolic Links in ${HOME}

  1. Issue the following commands

    $ cd
$ ln -s ${HOME}/Documents/Dropbox/ubuntu/anaconda3
$ ln -s ${HOME}/Documents/Dropbox/ubuntu/awstest
$ ln -s ${HOME}/Documents/Dropbox/ubuntu/.bash_aliases
$ rm .bash_logout
$ ln -s ${HOME}/Documents/Dropbox/ubuntu/.bash_logout
$ ln -s ${HOME}/Documents/Dropbox/ubuntu/.bash_profile
$ ln -s ${HOME}/Documents/Dropbox/ubuntu/.bashrc
$ ln -s ${HOME}/Documents/Dropbox/ubuntu/bin
$ ln -s ${HOME}/Documents/Dropbox/ubuntu/.emacs
$ ln -s ${HOME}/Documents/Dropbox/ubuntu/.emacs.d
$ ln -s ${HOME}/Documents/Dropbox/ubuntu/projects
$ ln -s ${HOME}/Documents/Dropbox/ubuntu/.ssh
$ ln -s ${HOME}/Documents/Dropbox/ubuntu/.thunderbird # This one should be already done.
$ ln -s ${HOME}/Documents/Dropbox/ubuntu/tools
$ ln -s ${HOME}/Documents/Dropbox/ubuntu/workspace
$ ln -s ${HOME}/Documents/Dropbox/ubuntu/.gitconfig
$ cd ~/.config
$ ln -s ${HOME}/Documents/Dropbox/ubuntu/.config/zim
$ cd ~/.local/share/applications
$ ln -s ${HOME}/Documents/Dropbox/ubuntu/.local/share/applications/gnome-terminal.desktop

  2. Log out and log back in

Set Up Terminal Preferences and Profiles

  1. Start a Terminal window
  2. Use the Terminal's menus to navigate to Terminal --> Preferences --> General
  3. Make sure Show menubar by default in new terminals and Enable the menu accelerator key (F10 by default) are checked
  4. Go to the Profiles tab
  5. Rename the Unamed profile to SystemDefault.
  6. Create CHPC1, CHPC2, hcpx-fs01, TimsPreferred profiles as follows
    • CHPC1
      • General: Columns: 132, Rows: 42
      • Colors: Use colors from system theme
    • CHPC2
      • General: Columns: 132, Rows: 42 * Colors: * uncheck Use colors from system theme * Built-in schemes: Custom * Text color: #000000 * Background color: #FCE9C0 * uncheck Use transparency from system theme
    • hcpx-fs01
      • General: Columns: 132, Rows: 42
      • Colors: * uncheck Use colors from system theme * Built-in schemes: Black on light yellow * uncheck Use transparency from system theme
    • TimsPreferred
      • General: Columns: 132, Rows: 42
      • Colors: * uncheck Use colors from system them * Built-in schemes: Solarized light * uncheck Use transparency from system theme
  7. Set defaut to TimsPreferred
  8. Test open terminals on all platforms

Change Desktop Background

  1. System Settings --> Apperance
  2. Change from Wallpapers to Colors & Gradients
  3. Select Color Gradient with down indicator, "v"
  4. Select Left color and set to pre-prepared light blue color
  5. Right Color stays black

Install Emacs

  1. Issue the following command

    $ sudo apt install emacs24-nox

Install Geany

  1. Issue the following commands

    $ sudo apt install geany
$ sudo add-apt-repository ppa:geany-dev/ppa
$ sudo apt-get update
$ sudo apt-get install geany geany-plugins

  2. Run Geany from the Dash

  3. Lock the Geany icon in the Launcher

  4. Enable Geany Plugins

    • Tools --> Plugin Manager
    • Check the following Plugins * Auto-close * Debugger * Extra Selection * File Browser * GeanyPy * GeanyVC * Git Change Bar * Macros * Numbered Bookmarks * Overview * Split Window * Updatechecker

Install Filezilla

  1. Issue the following commands

    $ sudo apt-get update
$ sudo apt-get install filezilla

  2. Add the following sites to the FileZilla Site Manager

    • fastmail ftp * Host: ftp.fastmail.com * Protocol: FTP * Logon Type: Normal * User: Get from KeePass2 * Password: Get from KeePass2
    • hcpcourse machine as admin * Host: 128.252.155.182 * Protocol: SFTP * Logon Type: Normal * User: Get from KeePass2 * Password: Get from KeePass2
    • hcpcourse machine as hcpcourse * Host: 128.252.155.182 * Protocol: SFTP * Logon Type: Normal * User: Get from KeePass2 * Password: Get from KeePass2

  3. Lock FileZilla to Launcher

Verify Anaconda Python 3 Environment

  1. Issue the following commands:

    $ source activate python3

  2. Make sure this gets you the Anaconda Python 3 environment with Nikola version v7.8.12 or higher installed

    $ nikola --version

Install Gnome2 Tools

  1. Issue the following commands

    $ sudo apt install libgnome2-bin

    This will give you access to commands line gnome-open

Install gitg

  1. Use the Ubuntu Software Center and search for gitg
  2. Install it
  3. Run it and make sure the icon is locked to the launcher

Install Unity Tweak Tool

  1. Use the Ubuntu Software Center and search for Tweak
  2. Install the Unity Tweak Tool instead of the Tweak Tool
  3. Unlock it from the launcher

Update Mouse Sensitivity

  1. See Fix Mouse Sensitivity in Ubuntu 16.04
  2. Try xset m 1/2 4 in the ~/.config/autostart/mouse.desktop file

Update Git

See the post Update Git

Set Up to Save Remote Git Username and Passwords

See the post How to save remote username and password for Git

Set Up Git FTP

See the section Preparing to deploy your site using git-ftp in the post Setting up Nikola, git, and git-ftp

Install Tkinter for Python

$ sudo apt-get update
$ sudo apt-get install python-tk
$ sudo apt-get install python3-tk

Configure Nautilus

  1. See How to Easily Add Custom Right-Click Options to Ubuntu's File Manager

  2. Install nautilus-actions

    $ sudo apt-get install nautilus-actions

  3. Log out and log back in in order to restart the Nautilus file manager.

  4. Run nautilus-actions from the Dash

  5. Add PrependModDate action - replace ${HOME} with actual path to home directory

    • Action * Check Display item in selection context menu * Check Display item in location context menu * Context Label: PrependModDate
    • Command * Path: ${HOME}/bin/PrependModDate * Parameters: %B * Working Directory: %d
    • Execution * Execution Mode: Normal

  6. Add RemoveNumbers action

    • Action * Check Display item in selection context menu * Check Display item in location context menu * Context Label: RemoveNumbers
    • Command * Path: ${HOME}/bin/remove_numbers * Parameters: empty * Working Directory: %d
    • Execution * Execution Mode: Normal

  7. Set up Nautilus Preferences

    • In Nautilus: Edit --> Preferences
      • Views * View new folders using: List View * Arrange Items: By Name * Check: Sort folders before files * Check: Show hidden and backup files
      • Behavior * Double click to open items * View executable text files when they are opened * Ask before emptying the Trash or deleting files
      • List Columns * Name, Size, Type, Modified
      • Preview
      • Files * Show thumbnails: Never
        • Folders * Count number of items: Local Files Only

Configure Date and Time Options

  1. Find the Time & Date settings in the System Settings App
  2. Select the Clock tab
  3. Check the following options
    • In the clock, show Weekday
    • In the clock, show Date and month
    • 24-hour time

Set Up for Mounting Remote File Systems

  1. Install sshfs

    $ sudo apt update
$ sudo apt install sshfs

  2. Create remote mount directory

    $ sudo su - root
# cd /mnt
$ mkdir chpc2
$ mkdir fs01

  3. Test mount CHPC2 file system

    $ mount_chpc2
$ cd /mnt/chpc2
$ ls

  4. Test mount fs01 file system

    $ mount_fs01
$ cd /mnt/fs01
$ ls

Install Search for Files Tool

  1. Install recoll

    $ sudo apt-get install recoll

  2. Install catfish

    $ sudo apt-get install catfish

  3. Run each to make sure recoll is indexing and to lock catfish icon to Launcher

Update to Latest Version of LibreOffice

  1. Remove the LibreOffice Icons from the Launcher

  2. Issue the following commands:

    $ sudo add-apt-repository ppa:libreoffice/ppa
$ sudo apt update
$ sudo apt install libreoffice

Add Screenshot Application to Launcher

  1. Search for the Screenshot application in the Dash
  2. Run it and lock the icon to the launcher

Make Directories for Mount Points

  1. Issue the following commands:

    $ sudo su - root
# cd /mnt
# mkdir chpc2
# chmod 777 chpc2
# mkdir fs01
# chmod 777 fs01
# mkdir ifs01
# chmod 777 ifs01
# exit

Set up Workspace Switcher

  1. Open Appearance from Dash

  2. Select Behavior tab

  3. Check Enable workspaces checkbox

  4. Run Unity Tweak Tool from Dash

  5. Select Workspace Settings under Window Manager

  6. Selecte Horizontal workspaces: 4 and Vertical workspaces: 1

  7. Install compiz

    $ sudo apt-get install compiz compizconfig-settings-manager compiz-plugins

  8. Run CompizConfig Settings Manager

  9. Select Window Management

  10. Check Workspace Naming and enable the necessar plugin

  11. Select Workspace Naming and name the workspaces: Administrative, Development, Pipeline Running and Checking, Misc

Install/Set Up Anaconda Python Distribution

Note

This should not be necessary

If you've got the Anaconda Python 3 files stored properly and linked to properly in Dropbox, then this configuration and setup should already be done.

  1. Download from https://www.continuum.io/downloads

  2. Find 64-Bit Pyton 3.x distribution

  3. Download the Anaconda installer script, e.g. Anaconda3-4.1.1-Linux-x86_64.sh

  4. Run the installer script: $ bash Anaconda3-4.1.1-Linux-x86_64.sh

  5. Create and activate a Python 3 environment

    $ conda create --name python3 python=3
$ source activate python3
$ conda install requests
$ conda list

Install and Configure VLC Media Player

  1. Visit: http://www.videolan.org/vlc/download-ubuntu.html
  2. Download and install
  3. Set VLC as default Music and Video application
    • Select Settings icon in upper right hand corner of screen
    • About this computer
    • Default Applications
    • Music: VLC Media Player
    • Video: VLC Media Player

Configure Terminal Keep Alive

  1. See http://askubuntu.com/questions/127369/how-to-prevent-write-failed-broken-pipe-on-ssh-connection
  2. Edit /etc/ssh/ssh_config
  3. Set ServerAliveInterval to 120

Install Miscellaneous Software Using Ubuntu Software Center

The following can all be install from the Ubuntu Software Center and then remove their icons from the launcher

  1. Alternatives Configurator
  2. Meld
  3. Okular
  4. pdfsam

Install Java JDK

See: https://thishosting.rocks/install-java-ubuntu/

  1. Install the Default JDK

    $ sudo apt install default-jdk default-jdk-doc

    This should get you Java 8

  2. Install Oracle's Java 9 JDK

    $ sudo apt-get update && sudo apt-get upgrade
$ sudo apt-get install software-properties-common
$ sudo add-apt-repository ppa:webupd8team/java
$ sudo apt-get update
$ sudo apt-get install oracle-java9-installer

  3. Configure default

    $ sudo update-alternatives --config java

    Select the Java you want to be your default and check/set your JAVA_HOME environment variable in your .bashrc file as necessary. The update-alternatives program sets up symbolic links such that:

    /usr/bin/java --> /etc/alternatives/java /etc/alternatives/java --> wherever you set it (e.g. /usr/lib/jvm/java-9-oracle/bin/java)

    But it doesn't seem to take care of setting the JAVA_HOME environment variable.

Install DragonDisk

  1. Visit http://www.s3-client.com/download-s3-compatible-cloud-client.html
  2. Download .deb file for amd64
  3. Open the .deb file in Ubuntu Software Center and install it.

Installing R and R Studio

  1. Install R itself

    $ sudo apt-get update
$ sudo apt-get install r-base

  2. Install RStudio

    • Visit https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/
    • Click RStudio Desktop link
    • Make sure you are getting the Open Source Edition and click the Download RStudio Desktop link, followed by the appropriate Download Now button, followed by the link for the Ubuntu 16.04/Debian 9+ (64-bit) installer
    • Open the .deb and install it with Ubuntu Software Center

Install Several Versions of MATLAB

  1. Visit https://www.mathworks.com

  2. Select the Login link

  3. Login to account (see KeePass2)

  4. In My Software list, by the Concurrent License for Academic Use, click the Download Link

  5. Download versions R2013a, R2014a, R2016b, and R2018a

    For each one:

    • Choose Linux 64-bit for each (of course)
    • Every product that is available for the platform should already be checked/selected
    • Click the Download ... Products button
    • Follow the instructions to download all the products into a download directory
    • Follow the instructions to install the product
    • Log in to MATLAB account during installation
    • When prompted for license file, use ${HOME}/Documents/Dropbox/MATLAB/network.lic as path to license file.
    • Instructions and procedures may be different for each version

Install/Enable SSH Server

References

  • See https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-set-up-ssh-keys--2

Steps

  1. Issue the following commands to install the ssh server:

    $ sudo apt-get install openssh-server

  2. Issue the following command to copy your ssh key (id_rsa.pub) to the machines you want to be able to easily ssh to.

    $ # The following is so you can ssh right back to the current workstation (leopardws01.wucon.wustl.edu)
$ # This is necessary for the Torque job scheduler
$ ssh-copy-id <your-login-id>@leopardws01.wucon.wustl.edu

    You should then be able to:

    $ ssh leopardws01
$ ssh <your-login-id>@leopardws01.wucon.wustl.edu

Install PBS/Torque Job Scheduler on the Workstation

References

  • Installing Torque/PBS job scheduler on Ubuntu 14.04 LTS/16.04 LTS
  • What is the difference between PBS and Torque
    • Torque is an open source implementation of PBS (Portable Batch System). It is a fork of OpenPBS (discontinued), but cannot use the PBS name due to trademark issues.
    • PBS and Torque consist of 3 pieces: pbs_server, pbs_sched, and pbs_mom.
    • The pbs_sched part can be replaced with the free MAUI scheduler or with the for pay MOAB scheduler.
    • Torque even allows you to write your own replacement for pbs_sched.
    • There is one pbs_server which interacts with the user.
    • There are many pbs_moms, one per compute node.
    • There is one pbs_sched (scheduler) which talks to the pbs_server and to the pbs_moms
    • I imagine that
      • The pbs_server gets requests for jobs to run from the user (via the qsub command).
      • The pbs_sched communicates with the pbs_server to learn what jobs have been requested. The pbs_sched then implements the scheduling policy.
      • The pbs_sched communicates with the pbs_mom on execution/compute nodes to actually cause jobs to start running.
      • This is just a guess at the basic architecture.
  • User Commands PBS/Torque Slurm ...
  • Some frequently used PBS commands
  • Other useful commands
    • pgrep -l pbs
    • pbsnodes -a

Information

  • FQDN: leopardws01.wucon.wustl.edu
  • Steps need to be done as root: sudo su - root

Steps

Credit to Installing Torque/PBS blog entry linked above. Steps copied here so as not to be dependent upon a blog whose author might decide to no longer maintain.

  1. Install the necessary software

    $ apt-get install torque-server torque-client torque-mom torque-pam

  2. Stop all torque services and create a clean setup

    $ /etc/init.d/torque-mom stop
$ /etc/init.d/torque-scheduler stop
$ /etc/init.d/torque-server stop
$ pbs_server -t create

  3. Kill the just-started server

    $ killall pbs_server

  4. Configure server process

    $ echo leopardws01.wucon.wustl.edu > /etc/torque/server_name
$ echo leopardws01.wucon.wustl.edu > /var/spool/torque/server_priv/acl_svr/acl_hosts
$ echo root@leopardws01.wucon.wustl.edu > /var/spool/torque/server_priv/acl_svr/operators
$ echo root@leopardws01.wucon.wustl.edu > /var/spool/torque/server_priv/acl_svr/managers

  5. Tell the server that this box itself is a compute node

    Specify 4 cores - which you can change

    $ echo leopardws01.wucon.wustl.edu np=4 > /var/spool/torque/server_priv/nodes

  6. Tell the MOM process which server to contact for work

    $ echo leopardws01.wucon.wustl.edu > /var/spool/torque/mom_priv/config

  7. Restart all the processes

    $ /etc/init.d/torque-server start
$ /etc/init.d/torque-scheduler start
$ /etc/init.d/torque-mom start

  8. Start the scheduler

    # set scheduling properties
$ qmgr -c 'set server scheduling = true'
$ qmgr -c 'set server keep_completed = 300'
$ qmgr -c 'set server mom_job_sync = true'

  9. Create a default queue (named 'batch', but you can change this)

    # create default queue
$ qmgr -c 'create queue batch'
$ qmgr -c 'set queue batch queue_type = execution'
$ qmgr -c 'set queue batch started = true'
$ qmgr -c 'set queue batch enabled = true'
$ qmgr -c 'set queue batch resources_default.walltime = 1:00:00'
$ qmgr -c 'set queue batch resources_default.nodes = 1'
$ qmgr -c 'set server default_queue = batch'

  10. Configure the server to allow submissions from itself

    # configure submission pool
$ qmgr -c 'set server submit_host = leopardws01'
$ qmgr -c 'set server allow_node_submit = true'

  11. Test by "submitting" an interactive job

    $ qsub -I

    You should get into a shell on the same box as if you ssh'ed to the same node.

  12. Check for running PBS processes

    $ pgrep -l pbs

    You should see 3 processes (something like)

    18030 pbs_server
18074 pbs_sched
18122 pbs_mon

    Note

    Sometimes on reboot, the pbs_sched process doesn't get started. Invoking the ~/bin/restart_torque script after a reboot should fix that problem for now. It needs to be investigated why started pbs_sched on boot-up doesn't seem to be working.

    Here's one possible place to start the investigation:

    https://stackoverflow.com/questions/36013057/all-jobs-in-q-queue-for-torque-pbs-scheduler

  13. Modify/configure the qpeek script

    • qpeek is a local Perl script instead of an actual PBS/Torque command
    • Edit ~/bin/qpeek and replace the like that looks like:
    my $host    = "mgt2.cluster" # or whatever host is listed

    with

    my $host    = "leopardws01.wucon.wustl.edu" # or what your FQDN is

item.title: Setting up Nikola, Git, and git-ftp
item.dc:creator: Software Development Training LLC
item.description:
Table of Contents

  • Useful Links
  • Assumptions
  • Substitutions in commands
  • Installation of Nikola
  • Associating your site source code with a GitHub Repository
  • Building and viewing your site locally
  • Preparing to deploy your site using git-ftp
  • Make a change to your content and build your site locally
  • Deploy your site
  • Notes

Useful Links

  • Nikola Getting Started Guide
  • The Nikola Handbook
  • git-ftp

Assumptions

The following assumes:

  • You already have a Python 3 environment set up using Anaconda.
  • You have git version 2.16.2 or later installed
  • You are working with your Python 3 and git tools at a bash shell

Substitutions in commands

Make the following substitutions in the commands below:

  • Substitute your Python 3 environment name for python3
  • Substitute the name of the directory in which you keep your source code projects for ~/projects
  • Substitute the sub-directory of ~/projects you want to use for the source code for your site for softdevtrain.com.

Installation of Nikola

  1. Start your Python 3 environment

    $ source activate python3

  2. Install prerequisite Python "Asset management application for Python web development"

    (python3) $ pip install webassets

  3. Ensure that pip and setuptools are up-to-date

    (python3) $ pip install --upgrade setuptools pip --ignore-installed

  4. Install Nikola

    (python3) $ pip install --upgrade "Nikola[extras]" --ignore-installed

Associating your site source code with a GitHub Repository

If you are starting a completely new site

  1. Create a GitHub repository for your site

    • Visit <https://github.com> and login to your GitHub account.
    • Select the New repository button
    • Name the repository softdevtrain.com (your site name)

    You should see the GitHub URL for your new (empty) repository. (e.g. https://github.com/your-user-id/softdevtrain.com.git)

  2. Clone your new (empty) GitHub repository

    (python3) $ cd ~/projects
(python3) $ git clone https://github.com/your-user-id/softdevtrain.com.git

  3. Verify that the ~/projects/softdevtrain.com directory has been created

  4. Initialize your site

    (python3) $ cd ~/projects
(python3) $ nikola init softdevtrain.com

    This should create the first version of your site in the softdevtrain.com sub-directory.

If you are working with a site for which a GitHub repository has already been created

  1. Clone the existing GitHub repository

    (python3) $ cd ~/projects
(python3) $ git clone https://github.com/your-user-id/softdevtrain.com.git

Building and viewing your site locally

  1. Build your site

    (python3) $ cd ~/projects/softdevtrain.com
(python3) $ nikola build

  2. View your site

    (python3) $ gnome-open output/index.html

    or

    (python3) $ nikola serve -b
    Ctrl-C when done

Preparing to deploy your site using git-ftp

Install git-ftp

(python3) $ sudo apt-get install git-ftp

Configure git-ftp

(python3) $ git config git-ftp.url "ftp://your-ftp-site/your-files-directory"
(python3) $ git config git-ftp.user "your-ftp-site-user-id"
(python3) $ git config git-ftp.password "your-ftp-site-password"
(python3) $ git config git-ftp.syncroot output/ # the output directory of a Nikola repository contains the built site to be deployed

Make a change to your content and build your site locally

For example:

(python3) $ nikola new_post

or

(python3) $ nikola new_post -e # make a new post and open up the editor specified in the EDITOR environment variable

Edit your post or content.

Then build the site with the following command:

(python3) $ nikola build

Deploy your site

If you have not uploaded any files to the ftp site and you want to completely upload all files to your site.

(python3) $ git ftp init

If you have previously uploaded files to your ftp site.

(python3) $ git ftp push

Notes

  1. Pushing to the ftp site does not cause the changes to be committed to your local repository or pushed to the origin remote repository.

    You will need to do git commit -m "comment" to commit changes locally before they can be pushed to the ftp site.

    You will need to do git push origin --all (or a similar command) to push your changes to the git repository.

  2. Your standard operating procedure after setup will usually be:

    Make or edit a post or page

    (python3) $ nikola new_post

    Build the site locally to see how your changes look

    (python3) $ nikola build

    See if it looks like what you like

    (python3) $ gnome-open output/index.html

    or

    (python3) $ nikola serve -b
Ctrl-C when done

    Commit changes to local repository and push them to remote (GitHub) repository

    (python3) $ git add *files*
(python3) $ git commit -m "commit comment"
(python3) $ git push origin --all

    Push the changes to the ftp site so they actually show up on your web site

    (python3) $ git ftp push
